If we compute the mean and standard error of the gathered data, we see that the time period of the pendulum should be 2.096 +/-0.020. This gives the range of the time period of the pendulum to be 2.076 to 2.106. However her prediction of 2.01 doesn't lie in the above range. Hence her data doesn't agree with her prediction.

While there isn't a whole lot of information given about this experiment, I believe the data doesn't agree with the prediction. The prediction of 2.01 s was a minimum of .21 s off, and was .27 s off of the average period. With this in mind, I believe the data doesn't agree with the prediction, as the data is more than a quarter of a second of from the prediction. A quarter of a second is quite a large difference in time when performing an experiment. I believe that the data would need to be within approximately .05 s of the prediction for me to decide that the data agrees with the prediction.
The range of values were all above the predicted value making it more likely that there is systematic error or the prediction is wrong

Using a t-test and the null hypothesis mu=2.01 and alternate hypothesis mu=/=2.01, I find a p-value of 0.0109, which is the probability of getting the given results or more extreme under the assumptions that the period is 2.01 seconds. Since this is vary unlikely to be a result of random error, I do not support the prediction and I reject the null hypothesis. There is probably some other factor that creates the difference in results.
all of the data points are above the expected value, if there were some points above and some below i would be more likely to say the data agrees.
